title: 115_hr1484
content: The "Social Worker Safety Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Additionally, there is a provision for a Social Worker Safety Grant Program. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award grants to States for safety measures for social workers and similar professionals working with at-risk populations. Funds can be used for safety equipment procurement, training for safety communications, self-defense, and crisis training. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award grants to States for safety measures for social workers and similar professionals working with at-risk populations. This includes facility safety improvements, cultural competency training, training on de-escalation strategies, working with clients with mental health or substance use disorders, educational resources for staff training, support services for social workers experiencing safety issues, and installation of a local data incident tracking system. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award grants to States for safety measures for social workers and similar professionals. States seeking grants must submit applications describing agencies receiving funding, specific activities, and program budgets. The Secretary prioritizes grants based on need and assistance to multiple agencies. Guidelines ensure quality and cost effectiveness of safety measures. Technical assistance may be provided to grant recipients for planning and implementing safety measures. States receiving a grant under this section must submit a report to the Secretary within 2 years, assessing funded activities, training opportunities for social workers, and strategies to address threats to their safety. The State must also agree to provide a non-federal share for safety measures funded by the grant. The State receiving the grant must provide non-Federal contributions equal to $1 for every $1 of Federal funds awarded. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and "social work" involves helping individuals, groups, or communities enhance social functioning. Social workers diagnose and treat mental and emotional disorders, as well as help individuals, families, or groups access various services to improve overall well-being. A social worker is an individual with a degree in social work who provides services for various entities in society. Authorization of Appropriations: $5,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2022 to carry out this section.
